title: Cutaneous Melanoma
diagnosis_topic: Pigmented skin lesion concerning for melanoma with staging and management considerations
setup_script: “A 38-year-old man presents to your clinic with a dark mole on his upper back that he has had for several years. Over the past few months, he has noticed that it has grown in size, become more irregular in color, and occasionally itches. He denies bleeding, ulceration, or systemic symptoms. His past medical history is unremarkable, but his father had a history of melanoma. On exam, you see a pigmented lesion with asymmetric borders and irregular color. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “You see a 9 mm asymmetric pigmented plaque with irregular borders and variegated pigmentation.”
“Findings are suspicious for melanoma with irregular pigment network and atypical dots.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs excisional biopsy with narrow margin
dynamic_flow.reply: “The lesion is completely excised. Pathology shows superficial spreading melanoma with Breslow depth 1.2 mm, no ulceration, mitotic rate 2/mm².”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans wide local excision
dynamic_flow.reply: “Based on Breslow depth, you plan a 1–2 cm margin excision. How would you close the defect?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers sentinel lymph node biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Sentinel lymph node biopsy is performed concurrently. Pathology reveals one sentinel lymph node positive for metastatic melanoma.”
“The patient returns after 6 months with enlargement of the excision site and new pigmented nodules. What would you do now?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders staging scans at initial diagnosis
dynamic_flow.reply: “CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and PET/CT are negative for metastatic disease.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses nodal management after positive sentinel node
dynamic_flow.reply: “You discuss options of completion lymphadenectomy versus active nodal surveillance with imaging, along with referral to medical oncology for adjuvant immunotherapy.”
“Medical oncology recommends adjuvant nivolumab. How do you counsel the patient regarding treatment and follow-up?”
“You counsel on skin self-examination, sun protection, and avoidance of tanning beds.”
“Genetic counseling is considered given family history of melanoma; CDKN2A mutation testing is offered.”
“You recommend dermatology and surgical follow-up every 3–6 months for 2 years, then annually.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to provide surveillance plan
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient is lost to follow-up and returns with multiple cutaneous and pulmonary metastases. How would you approach management now?”

critical_decision_points: Choice of biopsy technique for suspicious pigmented lesions
Use of Breslow depth to guide excision margins and sentinel lymph node biopsy
Management decisions based on sentinel node results
Patient education and long-term surveillance planning

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated solid diagnostic reasoning by recognizing melanoma as a likely diagnosis and ordering the correct biopsy. Your explanation of surgical margins and the role of sentinel lymph node biopsy was clear and well-structured. Communication with the patient about diagnosis and follow-up was empathetic and organized.Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition of the need for sentinel node biopsy and clear articulation of its indications would strengthen your management plan. You could also improve by integrating discussion of adjuvant immunotherapy and surveillance into your primary plan without prompting.Suggested Reading Topics: - NCCN Guidelines on Melanoma - Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy in Melanoma (SCORE Curriculum) - Principles of Wide Local Excision and Surgical Margins in Melanoma
